The Flood Warning has now been removed. 
The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels are rising on the Bristol Avon and the Semington Brook due to persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads, paths and farmland is possible today, the 19/12/22. Further heavy rainfall is forecast overnight and we anticipate the rivers will remain high until the 22/12/22. 
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford, the flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. No property flooding is currently expected. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Our incident response staff are checking and clearing debris from weed screens in the area.
From 17:00 on the 19/12/2022 until 09:00 on the 26/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be temporarily automated due to industrial action. We will be unable to update the content of this Flood Alert during that time.

items.message:
River levels remain high at Sherborne Lake gauge and are expected to rise at Chetnole and other river gauges as a result of heavy rain overnight.  
Consequently, flooding of roads, paths and farmland remains possible. We expect flooding to affect the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and please be careful at Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.   
Our incident response staff have checked assets, cleared weed screens and we are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please plan your routes to avoid low lying roads and paths near rivers which may be flooded and refer to the local authority website for local road closures.  
From 17:00 19/12/2022 until Boxing Day the flood warning service will be automated due to industrial action. We are unable to update the text in this message during automation.

items.description: Upper River Mole, Ifield Brook, Gatwick Stream and Burstow Stream
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ifield Brook, River Mole, Gatwick Stream, Burstow Stream

items.message:
River levels peaked yesterday19/12/2022 at 15:00 and are now falling. The rainfall forecasted for last night was not significant enough to cause any further flooding. The risk of flooding has now passed. 
The weather forecast is for a predominantly dry day throughout today, Tuesday 20/12/2022 with the next rainfall forecast for Thursday 22/12/22. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further flood alerts if necessary.

Water levels on the Eastern Yar are high following the rain over the last 48 hours. Levels are currently stable at Alverstone and continue to rise at Sandown. The river is out of bank at Whitwell and Langbridge. The river levels will restrict access to Horringford and be close to the top of the bank at Alverstone. Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road are flooded. Levels will be high at Sandown Bridge, the sewage treatment plant and Fort Holiday Park. A further 10mm of rain is forecast for the remainder of today and overnight. Levels at Alverstone will rise again. Be prepared for the river to be higher than normal for the next few days. The rainfall forecast is lower than it was this morning, but property flooding is still a possibility later on this evening (19/12/2022) and overnight. If you live near the river, take action now to protect your property. Between 17:00 on 19/12/2022 and 09:00 on 26/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Flooding is possible in this area.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

The River Ouse is high, following 30mm of rain Sunday. Minor flood impacts are expected to continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach properties all along the Upper Ouse. Including near Dean's Water Mill, Sloop Lane and Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. The Anchor Inn at Barcombe Mills will likely flood and Barcombe Mills Road could be impassable. Another 15mm of rain is possible through Monday evening and Tuesday morning. It is possible the River Ouse could rise a little higher Monday afternoon and Tuesday. With unsettled weather, the River Ouse through Barcombe could remain higher than normal all week. As a precaution, we recommend keeping flood protection products installed in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. Between 17:00 19/12/2022 and 09:00 26/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

items.description: The upper Stour and surrounding tributaries
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for some light rainfall for the next few days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

The Bull River is high but slowly falling, following 30mm of rain Sunday. Flooding will continue to affect properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. Flooding is also expected to continue affecting North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. A further 10-15mm of rain is possible from 18:00 Monday 19/12/2022, through to 09:00 Tuesday 20/12/2022. Which could cause river levels to rise higher and fall later. The Cuckmere River through Hellingly is currently rising, but no more than minor flood impacts are expected on Mill Lane Hellingly and Grove Hill near Grovebridge farm. River levels could remain higher than normal all week due to unsettled weather. Plan to avoid driving on routes vulnerable to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly and North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. Between 17:00 19/12/2022 and 09:00 26/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen on the river Mole from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham and Sidlow as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of roads and low lying land close to watercourses in the area is expected to continue until Wednesday morning 21/12/22. 
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 15 hours until tomorrow morning 20/12/22.  We expect river levels to remain high until Wednesday morning 21/12/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. 
This message will be updated by the morning of the 21/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury on the River Adur

items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for some light rainfall for the next few days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force for the Lower River Medway, and is likely to remain in force until Wednesday 21 December. Levels remain high following rainfall earlier on Monday and further rain is forecast Monday night into Tuesday. Levels will continue to rise gradually into the evening and overnight in all areas including Yalding, Wateringbury, East Farleigh and Maidstone. In all locations, levels could rise yet further on Tuesday morning as a result of any additional rainfall on Monday night. The internal flooding of property is not anticipated at the time of updating on Monday afternoon, and our best forecast is for levels not to exceed those of 18 November. Environment Agency operatives are checking our structures and assets to ensure the rivers can flow freely.  This message may not be updated again prior to removal later in the week.

The River Ouse is high, and very slowly rising at Barcombe Mills. In the last 48 hours, half a month's rain (40mm) has been recorded at Barcombe. From 17:00 on 19/12/2022, flooding is expected to affect the Anchor Inn. Water will be extensive through fields. Barcombe Mills Road and Anchor Lane could be impassable, but we do not currently expect property flooding in Barcombe Mills itself. There is the possibility of another 15mm of rain on Monday evening. River levels are not expected to rise significantly higher, but the fall towards normal could be delayed. The river should begin to fall by 16:00 on 20/12/2022, but with unsettled weather in the five-day outlook, the River Ouse in Barcombe might not return to normal until the end of the week. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. Deploy flood protection products as a precaution in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will likely remove this message on Tuesday 20/12/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
While the risk of flooding from rivers in Upper River Tamar has now reduced, a Flood Alert remains in force. Further rain is forecast late afternoon and overnight on Monday 19th December, and we expect river levels to rise overnight in response to this rainfall. We are not anticipating issuing any Flood Warnings. Conditions tomorrow are expected to improve with minimal rainfall currently forecast. 

Take care near the areas of concern and be aware of your local weather conditions. We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels throughout the evening and into tomorrow.

The Cuckmere River is high and rising, following 35mm of rain Sunday and Monday. Flooding will affect fields, rural roads, gardens, and properties including The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel, and properties near North Street, Willows Car Park and River Lane, Alfriston. Access along Litlington Road may be restricted by flood water. Another 15mm of rain is possible Monday evening and Tuesday morning. The river might not begin to fall until Tuesday afternoon 20/12/2022. With unsettled weather predicted for the next five days, the Cuckmere River might not return nearer to normal until the end of the week. Flood water can be deep and dangerous, please take care if walking near the river in Alfriston. Please plan to avoid driving on routes vulnerable to flooding, including North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. Between 17:00 19/12/2022 and 09:00 26/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the Middle Dorset Stour due to rainfall.
Areas most at risk include tributaries between Sturminster Newton and Wimborne.
Further rainfall is forecast this evening.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
From 17:00 19/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: The Eden and Eden Brook continue to rise steadily as a result of heavy rainfall in the previous 24 hours. Minor flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 5pm this evening, Monday 19 December and Wednesday morning, 21 December.  Further rainfall is due across Surrey and West Kent on Monday night into Tuesday morning and the Eden is expected to be peaking in all locations including Haxted, Edenbridge, Hever and Penshurst, during daylight hours on Tuesday. The internal flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking our assets and structures to ensure the river flows freely. This message may not be updated again until such time that this Flood Alert is removed.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary. 

We continue to monitor the situation. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Ravensbourne area in the London Boroughs of Lewisham, Bromley, Greenwich and Croydon
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Bromley, Croydon, Greater London, Greenwich, Lewisham

items.message:
Flooding is possible in this area.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

The Western Rother is high and rising between MIdhurst and Fittleworth, following 30mm of rain Sunday. Flood water will continue to be close to properties and affect fields, rural roads and gardens at Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth. Another 15mm of rain is possible Monday evening and through the early hours of Tuesday, which could cause the Western Rother to rise through all communities. However, only minimal flood impacts are expected between Liss and Stedham. Minor flood impacts could be prolonged between Midhurst and Fittleworth, with water very close to properties. The river might not  begin to fall until Tuesday afternoon 20/12/2022 and could remain higher than normal all week. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. Between 17:00 19/12/2022 and 09:00 26/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

The Langney Haven is high, following 40mm of rainfall Sunday. Flooding will continue to affect gardens of Langney Green. Fields and parkland including Shinewater Park will also be affected. Another 15mm of rain is possible Monday evening and Tuesday morning. If the rain falls in the Eastbourne area, flood water could get a little closer to properties on Langney Green. The river might not begin to fall until Tuesday afternoon, but with unsettled weather forecast for the next five days, river levels will remain higher than normal all week. As a precaution, we recommend keeping flood protection products installed at Langney Green, if you have them. We are operating our structures at Fence Bridge and Crumbles Gate to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. Between 17:00 19/12/2022 and 09:00 26/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

River levels on the River Roding have risen overnight and will continue to slowly rise throughout the day today, Tuesday 20th December following recent rain and snow melt.

The main areas of concern are Abridge and also Loughton where flooding of low lying land and roads is expected during the day today. 

Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur. 
No further rain is forecast today or tomorrow but river levels are likely to remain high over the next 2 to 3 days. We are not currently expecting property flooding. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff on standby to attend to any blockages in the river.
This message will be updated this evening or as the situation changes.

The River Lox is higher than normal and rising, following 25mm of rain Sunday. Minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads, and gardens along the length of the River Lox. Another 15mm of rain is possible Monday evening and Tuesday morning. If the River Lox receives all this rain, it could rise higher and flood water could approach properties near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. Minor flooding could also affect isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge, Dunsfold and on Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. The river should begin to fall by Tuesday afternoon, but with unsettled weather forecast for the next five days, the river could remain higher than normal all week. Please continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst, to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. Between 17:00 19/12/2022 and 09:00 26/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely through today, Monday 19th December 2022. River levels are gently rising, and may remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying land and riverside areas around Great Yeldham, Castle Hedingham, Sible Hedingham, Halstead, White Colne, Chappel, Fordstreet, and the Toppesfield Brook, and in Colchester between the A12 and East Street. There may be some further light rainfall overnight. The forecast is for further unsettled spells over the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 20th December.

The Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes are higher than normal, following 35mm of rain Sunday and Monday. Another 15mm of rain is possible Monday evening and through the early hours of Tuesday. If as much rain falls as predicted, from 21:00 19/12/2022, minor flooding could affect Marshall Close, Lake Lane and Barnham Road, Barnham and fields near Shripney Lane, parts of the car park at Tescos on Shripney Road and Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. The Aldingbourne Rife will peak lower than it was in November. The Aldingbourne Rife should begin to fall by 15:00 Tuesday 20/12/2022. However, river levels could remain higher than normal into January. As a precaution, we recommend keeping flood protection products installed in Barnham, if you have them. We routinely clear grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. Between 17:00 19/12/2022 and 09:00 26/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Monday evening 19/12/2022 and overnight into Tuesday.

Following heavy rainfall over the last 24 hours further spells of rain, heavy at times, are expected through the rest of Monday, overnight, and into Tuesday.  River levels will remain high throughout the early part of this week and will be extremely sensitive to further rainfall.

We may issue Flood Warnings as necessary.

Flooding to low lying land and roads is expected.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and will have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages.

items.message:
River levels have peaked, and the risk of flooding from the River Exe area has now reduced. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

Looking forward, further rain is forecast overnight (Tuesday 20th December) onwards, so keep an eye on the weather forecast. The next week remains unsettled with more rain forecast, bringing wet and windy conditions.

With the Christmas period approaching please review your flood plans and consider any additional resources required over the next 10 days to be prepared for possible localised flooding.

items.description: River Dart from Buckfastleigh to Totnes, including Staverton
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
The risk of flooding from the River Dart has now reduced. However, river levels are expected to remain high, and will be sensitive to further rainfall. Looking forward, further rain is forecast overnight (Tuesday 20th December) onwards, so keep an eye on the weather forecast. The next week remains unsettled with more rain expected, bringing wet and windy conditions. 

With the Christmas period approaching, please review your flood plans and consider any additional resources required over the next 10 days, to be prepared for possible localised flooding. 

Flood Alerts may still be in force for this area. We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue any further warnings or alerts should the situation change.

River levels remain high at Chiselborough and Ashford Mill river gauges and are expected to rise at all gauges as a result of overnight heavy rain. 
Consequently, flooding of roads, paths and farmland remains possible. 
We expect flooding to affect roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges. The lower River Parrett is forecast to be bankfull and overtopping could occur.  
Our incident response staff have checked assets, cleared weed screens and we are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please plan your routes to avoid low lying roads and paths near rivers which may be flooded and refer to the local authority website for local road closures. 
From 17:00 19/12/2022 until Boxing Day the flood warning service will be automated due to industrial action. We are unable to update the text in this message during automation.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Plym, Tory Brook, Long Brook

items.message:
The risk of flooding from the Plym and Tory Brook rivers has now reduced. The rain has cleared the area, and while there are isolated showers for the rest of Tuesday 20th December, river levels have peaked and will continue to fall gradually overnight. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. 

Looking forward further rain is forecast from Wednesday onwards, so keep an eye on the weather forecast. The next week remains unsettled with frontal systems moving in from the west or south-west, bringing wet and windy conditions.  

With the Christmas period approaching please review your flood plans and consider any additional resources required over the next 10 days to be prepared for possible localised flooding.

items.description: River Parrett (upper) from South Perrott to Thorney
items.message:
River levels are predicted to rise again at the Chiselborough river gauge as a result of overnight heavy rain. 
Consequently, flooding of roads, paths and properties is possible. On the morning of 20/12/22, we expect flooding to affect the River Parrett downstream of Gawbridge, the A356 at Chiselborough, the Norton Sub Hamdon to Stratton road and Parrett Works near Martock.
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. If you have further detailed information please let us know. 
Please plan your routes to avoid low lying roads and paths near rivers which may be flooded and refer to the local authority website for local road closures. 
From 17:00 19/12/2022 until Boxing Day the flood warning service will be automated due to industrial action. We are unable to update the text in this message during automation.

items.description: Rivers Stour and Iwerne at Stourpaine
items.message:
Flooding is expected in this area. This means properties are at risk of flooding.
Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.

The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Great Stour, East Stour, Aylesford Stream, Ruckinge Dyke, Whitewater Dyke, Stour

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 

The situation is improving, and no further flooding is expected in this area. River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. 

We continue to monitor the situation and will re-issue this flood alert if required.

River levels are rising steadily on the Lower Dorset Frome due to the heavy rainfall yesterday and overnight. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham. Further rain is forecast for today so we will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

items.description: Rivers Otter and Sid, and Exmouth area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Monday evening 19/12/2022 and overnight into Tuesday.

Following heavy rainfall over the last 24 hours further spells of rain, heavy at times, are expected through the rest of Monday, overnight, and into Tuesday.  River levels will remain high throughout the early part of this week and will be extremely sensitive to further rainfall.

We may issue Flood Warnings as necessary.

Flooding to low lying land and roads is expected.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and will have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
The risk of flooding from the River Yealm has now reduced. Overnight rain has cleared the area, and while there are isolated showers throughout Tuesday 20th December, river levels have peaked and will continue to fall gradually through the day. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. 

Looking forward further rain is forecast from Wednesday onwards, so keep an eye on the weather forecast. The next week remains unsettled with frontal systems moving in from the west or south-west, bringing wet and windy conditions.  

With the Christmas period approaching please review your flood plans and consider any additional resources required over the next 10 days to be prepared for possible localised flooding.

Flooding is expected in this area. This means properties are at risk of flooding.
Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.

The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

The Flood Alert has now been removed.
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
From 17:00 19/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation

items.message:
Flooding is possible in this area.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

The water level in the River Blackwater at Ower and Cadnam River is high and rising. In the last 24 hours, heavy rain (30mm) has been recorded in Romsey. This is a large amount of rain in a short time. From this evening (19/12/2022), the river will flood land and roads at Cadnam, West Wellow, Landford and Ower. Water levels will be high around the mill building at East Wellow. In the next 24 hours, further rain is forecast, up to 15mm is expected. Given the amount of rain currently affecting the area, by tomorrow (20/12/2022) it is possible that a Flood Warning will be issued for the onset of isolated property flooding. We continue to monitor the forecast. Our operations staff will work to ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure that pumps used to protect property are operating correctly. From 17:00 on 19/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: The River Medway continues to rise steadily as a result of heavy rainfall in the previous 24 hours. Minor flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 6pm this evening, Monday 19 December and Wednesday morning, 21 December.  Further rainfall is due across Kent on Monday night into Tuesday morning and the Medway is expected to be peaking in all locations between Tonbridge and Yalding, including East Peckham, during daylight hours on Tuesday. The internal flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking our assets and structures to ensure the river flows freely. This message may not be updated again until such time that this Flood Alert is removed.

items.description: River Beult from Pluckley and Bethersden to Stilebridge
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force for the Upper River Beult, and is likely to remain in force until Tuesday 20 December or Wednesday 21 December. Levels remain high following rainfall earlier on Monday and further rain is forecast Monday night into Tuesday. Levels show signs of peaking at Bethersden and Smarden, but will continue to rise gradually at Stile Bridge, near Staplehurst, into the evening. In all locations, levels could rise yet further on Tuesday morning as a result of any additional rainfall on Monday night. The internal flooding of property is not anticipated at the time of updating on Monday afternoon. Environment Agency operatives are checking our structures and assets to ensure the rivers can flow freely.  This message may not be updated again prior to removal later in the week.

items.message:
Flooding is possible in this area.

River levels are forecast to rise on the River Ure due to rainfall and snowmelt higher up in the catchment.

Flooding is forecast to affect low lying locations near the River Ure from this evening 19/12/2022, particularly in the areas between Westwick Weir and Aldwark Bridge. This includes access roads around Lower Dunsforth which may be affected by rising water levels.

Levels on the Lower River Ure are expected to peak later on Tuesday 20/12/2022, before falling. 

We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ure, Swinney Beck, Bishop Monkton Beck, River Skell, River Laver, River Tutt, Stainley Beck

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Ure due to rainfall and snowmelt higher up in the catchment.

Flooding is forecast to affect low lying locations near the River Ure from this evening 19/12/2022, particularly in the areas between Westwick Weir and Aldwark Bridge.

River levels are now beginning to peak at the Kilgram gauge (upstream), but will remain high tonight before falling in the early hours of Tuesday morning. Levels on the Lower River Ure will peak later on Tuesday, before falling. 

We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

River levels are rising at the Stapleford river gauge as a result of recent rainfall and snowmelt. Consequently, flooding of property/roads and farmland is possible today and into tomorrow, 19/12/22 and 20/12/2022. We expect flooding to affect River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach.   

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high during this period.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  

This alert will be removed when river levels drop back below the alert threshold. 

Please avoid contact with flood water.

Looking forward, further rain is forecast overnight (Tuesday 20th December) onwards, so keep an eye on the weather forecast. The next week remains unsettled with more rain expected, bringing wet and windy conditions. 
 
With the Christmas period approaching please review your flood plans and consider any additional resources required over the next 10 days to be prepared for possible localised flooding.

items.description: River Axe (Lower) from Axminster to Axmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected on Monday evening (19/12/22) and into the early hours of Tuesday.

Heavy rain falling across the East Devon area over the last 24 hours, has caused the River Axe to rise rapidly. Continued heavy rainfall is forecast with water levels expected to peak and flooding to occur in the early hours of Tuesday.

We expect flooding to affect properties and low lying areas around Whitford Road between Whitford and Musbury, the A3052 at Colyford, the A35 at Yarty Bridge, Seaton Marshes. Farms and other isolated properties between Axminster and Axmouth will start to flood first. Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now and install any flood protection products you may have. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded.

We are constantly monitoring river levels and will have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels peaked yesterday at midday and are now falling. The rainfall forecasted for last night was not significant enough to cause any further flooding. The risk of flooding has now passed. The weather forecast is for a predominantly dry evening, Tuesday 20 December 2022 with the next rainfall forecast for Thursday 22 December 2022. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further flood alerts if necessary.

items.description: Rivers Yeo and Parrett, downstream of Yeovil to Steart

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Parrett, River Yeo, Cary, Sowy, Kings Sedgemoor Drain

items.message:
River levels remain high at Pen Mill river gauge and are expected to rise at all gauges as a result of overnight heavy rain. Consequently, flooding of roads, paths and farmland remains possible. 
We expect flooding to affect the following roads: the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of the runway, the Mudford to Limington road and the road at the south end of Westover Trading Estate. Properties at Westover Trading Estate at Langport are at risk. Bankfull conditions are forecast at Ilchester, water may reach the bottom of the ringbanks.
Our incident response staff have checked operational assets, the Parrett Relief channel is running, and some pumping stations are becoming inhibited by the high river levels. We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please plan your routes to avoid low lying roads and paths near rivers which may be flooded and refer to the local authority website for local road closures.  
From 17:00 19/12/2022 until Boxing Day the flood warning service will be automated due to industrial action. We are unable to update the text in this message during automation.

River levels are predicted to rise again at the Chetnole river gauge as a result of overnight heavy rain.  
Consequently, flooding of roads, paths and properties is possible. 
On the morning of 20/12/22, we expect flooding to affect the Chubbs Farm area and at Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole; please ensure you avoid the ford.   
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. If you have further detailed information please let us know.
Please plan your routes to avoid low lying roads and paths near rivers which may be flooded and refer to the local authority website for local road closures.  
From 17:00 19/12/2022 until Boxing Day the flood warning service will be automated due to industrial action. We are unable to update the text in this message during automation.

items.description: The Mardyke to the River Thames at Purfleet
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely through today, Monday 19th December 2022. River levels are gently rising, and may remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas along the River Mardyke between North Stifford and Purfleet. There may be some further light rainfall overnight. The forecast is for further unsettled spells over the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 20th December.

items.message:
Flooding is possible in this area.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Flooding is expected in this area. This means properties are at risk of flooding.
Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.

The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.
